In people who are treated at F2-F4 and are sustained responders, fibrosis stage reverses at −0.591 (−0.627;−0.550) steps per year.
Sustained response only occurred in 31% of people in the F2-F4 categories. However this study included numerous observations of people who had treatments that weren't effective. 
Sustained virologic response appears to be worse in treating people with cirrohsis
Poynard 2002 Impact of pegylated interferon alfa-2b and ribavirin on liver fibrosis in patients with chronic hepatitis C

Marcellin and Poynard agree: in 5-6 years, at -0.591 stages per year, an improvement of 3.25 stages

"In 62% of patients, the last biopsy done showed normal or nearly normal histologic findings." Last biopsy was 5-6 years

Dore et al. 2003, Epidemiology of hepatitis C virus infection in Australia

Retrospective testing of stored serum from two haemophilia centres in Melbourne demonstrated a HCV prevalence of 45% among people with haemophilia in 1973, rising to 74% by 1980 (Leslie et al., 1992). Similar retrospective testing of stored serum from IDUs presenting with acute hepatitis to Fairfield Hospital, Melbourne (Moaven et al., 1993) and IDUs attending a methadone maintenance clinic in Sydney (Freeman et al., 2000), demonstrated HCV prevalence of 70–84% in the early 1970s.
....
This risk was highest for those people, such as male haemophiliacs, who received blood product transfusions from multiple donors: in 1990, an HCV prevalence of approximately 75% was reported among people with haemophilia in Melbourne (Williamson et al., 1990).

During this period, it exceeded mortality in the general population by a factor of 2.69 (95% confidence interval [CI]: 2.37-3.05), and median life expectancy in severe hemophilia was 63 years.

Not a great ref, but
http://www.haemophilia.org.au/bleedingdisorders/fast-facts
The purpose of this factor is to accomodate for concerns that the AIHW Household Drug Surveys fail to capture people who inject drugs accurately. This factor inflates the results slightly.

The purpose of this variable is to adjust the data of AIHW results by a set amount to acknowledge the uncertainty in the data results. The results are given in percentages of increaments 0.1%. Being off by 0.1% across the size of the estimated population would result being off by an average of 1700. On rounding error alone, the error will be 1/4 of 1700. However, some results are out by over 50% (standard error 50%) on estimtes of 0.4%. As such, we have chosen uncertainty SD of 1700.

This parameter indiactes the level of entry into the IDU population as a proprtion of the peak. e.g. as time goes to infinity, IDU.Entry.B=0.25 indicates that entry would be 25% of that at the peak.

This parameter indicates how quickly the rate of entry into the injecting population declines towards zero going back in time. e.g., a setting of IDU.Entry.Logk1=0.9 indicates that one year before reaching the peak, entry into the injecting population was 90% of what it was at the peak. 2 years before that it was 0.9*0.9=0.81

This parameter indicates how quickly the rate of entry into the injecting population declines towards the rate set by Entry.B. e.g., a setting of IDU.Entry.Logk2=0.3 indicates that after reaching the peak of entry into the IDU population, the entry rate declines 30% of the distance from the peak ot what the final level will be at IDU.Entry.B
This is the maximium rate at which people become IDU, which happened around the late 1990s

Based on calculations form the ANSP Survey, the rate prior to 1997 is ~30%, and post 1997 is ~15%. See "Receptive Sharing Risk.xlsx" for calculations.
Based on calculations form the ANSP Survey, the rate prior to 1997 is ~30%, and post 1997 is ~15%. See "Receptive Sharing Risk.xlsx" for calculations.

This parameter indicates the relative risk by age of receptively sharing needles going from the age of 18 to the age of 40. It is based off:
The relationship between age and risky injecting behaviours among a sample of Australian people who inject drugs.
http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23664499

Calculations related to this figure can be found in the file "Receptive sharing risk.xlsx"

Note that the upper limit of 2 is because theoretically the rate of sharing could go up with age, although it is unlikely.
